    ```
    | group count(event.login.loginIsSuccessful=false), one=estimate_distinct(event.login.loginIsSuccessful where event.login.loginIsSuccessful=false)
    ```
    
    | count(event.login.loginIsSuccessful=false) | one |
    | --- | --- |
    | 6 | 1 |
    
    **Example Queries for Log Analytics**
    
    Consider these events:
    
    | status | serverHost | timestamp |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 404 | web1 | Jan 9 · 8:00:00.000 pm |
    | 200 | web2 | Jan 9 · 9:00:00.000 pm |
    | 404 | web2 | Jan 9 · 9:55:52.654 pm |
    | 404 | web2 | Jan 9 · 9:55:52.694 pm |
    | 200 | web1 | Jan 9 · 10:00:00.000 pm |
    | 200 | web2 | Jan 9 · 11:00:00.000 pm |
    | 404 | web1 | Jan 10 · 12:09:42.142 am |
    | 404 | web1 | Jan 10 · 12:09:42.153 am |
    | 200 | web2 | Jan 10 · 12:09:42.153 am |
    | 500 | web1 | Jan 10 · 12:09:42.682 am |
    
    Without the `by` clause, the aggregation function applies to all data from the previous command. The result is a single value:
    
    ```
    status = 404
    | group count()
    ```
    
    count()
    
    ---
    
    5
    
    ---
    
    With the `by` clause, data is divided into groups. Each expression is usually a field name, and data is grouped by each distinct field value. The aggregation function applies to each group, and the result is a table of statistics:
    
    ```
    status = *
    | group count() by status
    ```
    
    | status | count() |
    | --- | --- |
    | 200 | 4 |
    | 404 | 5 |
    | 500 | 1 |
    
    When you set multiple `by` expressions, for example `by status, serverHost`, each group is a unique combination of the expressions' values:
    
    ```
    status=*
    | group count() by status, serverHost
    ```
    
    | status | serverHost | count() |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 200 | web1 | 1 |
    | 200 | web2 | 3 |
    | 404 | web1 | 3 |
    | 404 | web2 | 2 |
    | 500 | web1 | 1 |
    
    Create a time series with `by` and the `timebucket()` function. Assign the name `timestamp`, a [Special Field](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006740), to show human-readable strings:
    
    ```
    status=*
    | group count() by serverHost, timestamp=timebucket('1h')
    ```
    
    | serverHost | timestamp | count() |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | web1 | Jan 9 · 8:00:00.000 pm | 1 |
    | web1 | Jan 9 · 10:00:00.000 pm | 1 |
    | web1 | Jan 10 · 12:00:00.000 am | 3 |
    | web2 | Jan 9 · 9:00:00.000 pm | 3 |
    | web2 | Jan 9 · 11:00:00.000 pm | 1 |
    | web2 | Jan 10 · 12:00:00.000 am | 1 |
    
    To calculate the latest status:
    
    ```
    status = *
    | group status=newest(status) by serverHost
    ```
    
    | serverHost | status |
    | --- | --- |
    | web1 | 500 |
    | web2 | 200 |
    
    The `where` clause lets you limit an aggregation function to selected events. For count(), the word "where" is not necessary. For example:
    
    ```
    status=*
    | group '404'=count(status=404), else=count(status!=404), web1=any(serverHost where status=500)
    ```
    
    | 404 | else | web1 |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 5 | 5 | web1 |
    
    ## Group Command - Aggregate Functions
    
    You can use these functions with the `group` command.
    
    | Function | Description |
    | --- | --- |
    | count() | Counts the number of records in the group. |
    | count(expression) | Counts the number of records where the expression is true, not zero, or not empty. |
    | sum(expression) | Sums all non-null inputs. If there are no eligible inputs, the result is 0. |
    | avg(expression) | Averages all inputs. The result is `NaN` if there are no eligible inputs. `null` values are ignored. `avg()`, `average()`, and `mean()` are interchangeable. |
    | min(expression) | The smallest input. The result is `NaN` if there are no eligible inputs. `null` values are ignored. |
    | max(expression) | The largest input. The result is `NaN` if there are no eligible inputs. `null` values are ignored. |
    | median(expression) | The median input. The result is `NaN` if there are no eligible inputs. `null` values are ignored. |
    | pct(NN, expression) | A percentile of the inputs. NN is a number from 0 to 100. For example, `pct(99.9, latency)` yields the 99.9th percentile of the `latency` field. The result is `NaN` if there are no eligible inputs. `null` values are ignored. |
    | p10(expression) | The 10th percentile of the inputs. Ignores `null`, `NaN`, and non-numeric input. |
    | p50(expression) | The 50th percentile of the inputs, as does `median()`. `null` values are ignored. |
    | p90(expression) | The 90th percentile of the inputs. `null` values are ignored. |
    | p95(expression) | The 95th percentile of the inputs. `null` values are ignored. |
    | p99(expression) | The 99th percentile of the inputs. `null` values are ignored. |
    | p999(expression) | The 99.9th percentile of the inputs. `null` values are ignored. |
    | stddev(expression) | The standard deviation of the inputs. The result is `NaN` if there are no eligible inputs. `null` values are ignored. |
    | array_agg(expression) | Creates an array of all values (including duplicates) from a PowerQuery column. The sequence in which the values are collected is undefined. Example, `| group all_ips_by_user = array_agg(ip) by user`. |
    | array_agg(expression, max_count) | Same as above, but limits the array size to `max_count`. Example, `| group ten_ips_per_user = array_agg(ip, 10) by user`. |
    | array_agg_distinct(expression) | Creates an array of unique values from a PowerQuery column. Example, `| group distinct_ips_by_user = array_agg_distinct(ip) by user`. |
    | array_agg_distinct(expression, max_count) | Same as above, but limits the array size to `max_count`. The sequence in which the values are collected is undefined. Example, `| group distinct_ips_by_user = array_agg_distinct(ip, 10) by user`. |
    | any(expression) | An arbitrary input. If there are no inputs, the result is `null`. |
    | any_true(expression) | `true` if the expression evaluates to true for any row in a group, otherwise `false`. Example, `group any_failures = any_true(status >= 400 && status <= 599) by serverHost`. |
    | all_true(expression) | `true` if the expression evaluates to true for all rows in a group, otherwise `false`. Example, `group complete_success = all_true(status >= 200 && status <= 299) by serverHost`. |
    | estimate_distinct(expression) | Estimates the number of distinct values in the inputs. `null` and `NaN` count as values. We use the HyperLogLog algorithm, configured for 1.3% median error. The result will generally be correct within 1-2 percent, even if there are millions of unique values. The result is exact if there are a small number of unique values. |
    | first(expression) | The first input. Requires a `sort` command before `group` to order the input table. |
    | last(expression) | The last input. Requires a `sort` command before `group` to order the input table. |
    | max_by(x,y) | The value of `x` from the row with the largest value of `y` in a group. Rows where `x` or `y` are `null` are ignored. If `y` is not numeric, the result is an unspecified value of x. Example, `group most_purchased_item = max_by(item_name, purchase_count) by account`. |
    | min_by(x,y) | The value of `x` from the row with the smallest value of `y` in a group. Rows where `x` or `y` are `null` are ignored. If y is not numeric, the result is an unspecified value of `x`. Example, `group least_purchased_item = min_by(item_name, purchase_count)`. |
    | newest(expression) | The input with the newest timestamp. Cannot be used after `group`, `sort`, or `limit`, because these commands use intermediate tables. |
    | oldest(expression) | The input with the oldest timestamp. Cannot be used after `group`, `sort`, or `limit`, because these commands use intermediate tables. |
    
    See [here](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006604#UUID-b02bf660-7e44-f4c4-5837-71e03e181c6d_UUID-f0240d6c-bb60-796e-1dfa-6b77924b2fa2) for more examples of how to use the `group` command.
    
    ## Group Command - Example Queries
    
    Consider these events:
    
    | status | serverHost | timestamp |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 404 | web1 | Jan 9 · 8:00:00.000 pm |
    | 200 | web2 | Jan 9 · 9:00:00.000 pm |
    | 404 | web2 | Jan 9 · 9:55:52.654 pm |
    | 404 | web2 | Jan 9 · 9:55:52.694 pm |
    | 200 | web1 | Jan 9 · 10:00:00.000 pm |
    | 200 | web2 | Jan 9 · 11:00:00.000 pm |
    | 404 | web1 | Jan 10 · 12:09:42.142 am |
    | 404 | web1 | Jan 10 · 12:09:42.153 am |
    | 200 | web2 | Jan 10 · 12:09:42.153 am |
    | 500 | web1 | Jan 10 · 12:09:42.682 am |
    
    Without the `by` clause, the aggregate function applies to all data from the previous command. The result is a single value:
    
    ```
    status = 404
    | group count()
    ```
    
    count()
    
    ---
    
    5
    
    ---
    
    With the `by` clause, data is divided into groups. Each expression is usually a field name, and data is grouped by each distinct field value. The aggregate function applies to each group, and the result is a table of statistics:
    
    ```
    status = *
    | group count() by status
    ```
    
    | status | count() |
    | --- | --- |
    | 200 | 4 |
    | 404 | 5 |
    | 500 | 1 |
    
    When you set multiple `by` expressions, for example `by status, serverHost`, each group is a unique combination of the expressions' values:
    
    ```
    status=*
    | group count() by status, serverHost
    ```
    
    | status | serverHost | count() |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 200 | web1 | 1 |
    | 200 | web2 | 3 |
    | 404 | web1 | 3 |
    | 404 | web2 | 2 |
    | 500 | web1 | 1 |
    
    Create a time series with `by` and the `timebucket()` function. Assign the name `timestamp`, a [Special Field](https://community.sentinelone.com/document/preview/1923128#UUID-fa1f399c-02ac-f13f-9111-45401c21178d), to show human-readable strings:
    
    ```
    status=*
    | group count() by serverHost, timestamp=timebucket('1h')
    ```
    
    | serverHost | timestamp | count() |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | web1 | Jan 9 · 8:00:00.000 pm | 1 |
    | web1 | Jan 9 · 10:00:00.000 pm | 1 |
    | web1 | Jan 10 · 12:00:00.000 am | 3 |
    | web2 | Jan 9 · 9:00:00.000 pm | 3 |
    | web2 | Jan 9 · 11:00:00.000 pm | 1 |
    | web2 | Jan 10 · 12:00:00.000 am | 1 |
    
    To calculate the latest status:
    
    ```
    status = *
    | group status=newest(status) by serverHost
    ```
    
    | serverHost | status |
    | --- | --- |
    | web-1 | 500 |
    | web-2 | 200 |
    
    The `where` clause lets you limit an aggregation function to selected events. For count(), the word "where" is not necessary. For example:
    
    ```
    status=*
    | group '404'=count(status=404), else=count(status!=404), web1=any(serverHost where status=500)
    ```
    
    | 404 | else | web1 |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 5 | 5 | web1 |
- PowerQuery let command
    
    The `let` command creates new fields from your data. The command can perform calculations and string manipulation of field values.
    
    ```
    | let field=expression, "field 2"=expression2, ...
    ```
    
    Examples:
    
    ```
    | let rfc1918 = not (dst.ip.address matches "((127\\..*)|(192\\.168\..*)|(10\\..*)|(172\\.1[6-9]\\..*)|(172\\.2[0-9]\\..*)|(172\\.3[0-1]\\..*)).*")
    | let indicators_of_interest = indicator.category="Evasion" ? "Evasion" : indicator.category="InfoStealer" ? "InfoStealer" : "All Others"
    | let loginSuccessRatePercent = count(event.login.loginIsSuccessful=false) / (count(event.login.loginIsSuccessful=false) + count(event.login.loginIsSuccessful=true)) * 100
    ```
    
    Examples for Log Analytics:
    
    ```
    | let isError = (status >= 500 && status <= 599)
    | let type = message contains 'application server' ? 'application' : message contains 'image server' ? 'image' : 'some other server'
    | let errorRate = (failedOperation / (failedOperation + successfulOperation ) * 100 )
    ```
    
    `let` cannot overwrite a field name from a preceding command. You *can* reuse (overwrite) field names in the event data.
    
    **Example queries**
    
    A query for outbound PowerShell, by hostname:
    
    ```
    // Outbound communications, grouped and sorted by IP, with counts for the environment
    src.process.name contains "powershell" dst.ip.address = *
    | let rfc1918 = not (dst.ip.address matches "((127\\..*)|(192\\.168\..*)|(10\\..*)|(172\\.1[6-9]\\..*)|(172\\.2[0-9]\\..*)|(172\\.3[0-1]\\..*)).*")
    | filter rfc1918 = true
    | group hits = count(src.process.name), IPs = hacklist(dst.ip.address) byendpoint.name,src.process.name,src.process.storyline.id
    | sort -hits
    ```
    
    **Example queries for Log Analytics**
    
    Consider these events in the `message` field:
    
    message
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:11.978 +0000 invoked application server: request=x984313696, timeMs=311, status=failure
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:12.190 +0000 invoked application server: request=x529894774, timeMs=15, status=success
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:12.958 +0000 invoked image server: request=x793874683, timeMs=10, status=success
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:13.033 +0000 invoked application server: request=x623461404, timeMs=230, status=success
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:13.251 +0000 invoked application server: request=x64452742, timeMs=12, status=success
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:13.317 +0000 invoked image server: request=x963265726, timeMs=6, status=success
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:13.752 +0000 invoked image server: request=x910264259, timeMs=6, status=success
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:14.009 +0000 invoked application server: request=x597856588, timeMs=21, status=success
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:14.062 +0000 invoked application server: request=x309410584, timeMs=509, status=failure
    
    ---
    
    17/Jan/2023:23:18:14.630 +0000 invoked image server: request=x594706419, timeMs=13, status=success
    
    ---
    
    To calculate the mean request time:
    
    ```
    message contains 'invoked'
    | let type= message contains 'application server' ? 'application' : message contains 'image server' ? 'image' : 'some other server type'
    | group mean(timeMs) by type
    ```
    
    | type | mean(time) |
    | --- | --- |
    | application | 183.00 |
    | image | 8.75 |
    
    To calculate the error rate for all events:
    
    ```
    message contains 'invoked'
    | group successfulOperation=count(status='success'), failedOperation=count(status='failure')
    | let errorRate = (failedOperation / (failedOperation + successfulOperation ) * 100 )
    ```
    
    | successfulOperation | failedOperation | errorRate |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 8 | 2 | 20 |
- PowerQuery parse command
    
    The `parse` command extracts new fields from a field.
    
    ```
    | parse "format ... $fieldToExtract$ ..." from fieldname
    ```
    
    Examples:
    
    ```
    | parse ".*\\\\$filename{regex=[^\\\\]+}$$$" from tgt.file.path
    | parse "Agent-$agentId$" fromendpoint.name"
    | parse "\\w+-$agentID$" fromendpoint.name
    | parse "Agent-$agentID=identifier$" fromendpoint.name
    ```
    
    Example for Log Analytics:
    
    ```
    | parse "image conversion processed $size$KB in $time$ seconds"
    | parse "image conversion processed $size{regex=\\d+}$"
    | parse "image conversion processed \\d+$units$"
    | payment authorized for $$$amount$
    ```
    
    The command is often unnecessary for EDR and XDR, because the data has a well-defined schema. One valuable use-case is the extraction of information from from paths, for example the filename.
    
    For other data, such as logs ingested through the SentinelOne Collector, the unparsed text of an event is often put in the `message` field. Parse lets you extract fields from unstructured, or semi-structured data.
    
    The "format" string can be any substring, and does not have to begin at the start of the line. Enclose the field to extract in `$` characters. For example:
    
    ```
    | parse "Agent-$agentId$" fromendpoint.name"
    ```
    
    If the field to extract has a `$`, escape it with `$`.
    
    Set the `{regex= }` flag to define the field as a regular expression. You must double escape regex elements:
    
    ```
    | parse "$exeProcesses{regex=\\w+.exe}$" fromsrc.process.name"
    ```
    
    You can also set a regular expression in "format" without a flag.
    
    ```
    | parse "\\w+-$agentID$" fromendpoint.name
    ```
    
    To test a regular expression:
    
    ```
    | limit 1
    | columns test="foo\\bar\\baz.exe"
    | parse ".*\\\\$filename{regex=[^\\\\]+}$" from test
    ```
    
    | test | filename |
    | --- | --- |
    | foo\bar\baz.exe | bar |
    
    You can use `$$` to match from the end of a line:
    
    ```
    | limit 1
    | columns test="foo\\bar\\baz.exe"
    | parse ".*\\\\$filename{regex=[^\\\\]+}$$$" from test
    ```
    
    | test | filename |
    | --- | --- |
    | foo\bar\baz.exe | baz.exe |
    
    See [Regex](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006624) for more.
    
    Set `=digits` and `=identifier` to extract digits and strings:
    
    ```
    | parse "Agent-$agentID=identifier$" fromendpoint.name
    ```
    
    The field name cannot be a name from a previous command. You can reuse (overwrite) field names in the event data.
    
    Field names can have `.` dots, `_` underscores, and `-` hyphens. You must escape slashes in Event Search and PowerQueries. For example, write the field name [`app.kubernetes.io/component`](http://app.kubernetes.io/component) as [`app.kubernetes.io](http://app.kubernetes.io/)\/component`.
    
    Tips:
    
    - We recommend the above `| limit 1 | columns test=....` syntax to build and troubleshoot a regular expression.
    - Include a `filter` command before `parse` to make sure all events have the expected format. This improves performance, and prevents garbage output.
    - Most use cases for `parse` can be eliminated with a parser. You can graph parsed fields, and they query faster.
    
    **Examples for Log Analytics :**
    
    Consider these servers that run in regions 1, 2, and 3:
    
    ```
    appserver-1
    appserver-2
    appserver-3
    web-1
    web-2
    web-3
    ```
    
    A web access log on each server records HTTP status codes for each request. To calculate the error rate for the web and application servers:
    
    ```
    status=*
    | parse "$app{regex=\\w+}$" from serverHost
    | group success = count(status >= 200 && status <=299), error = count(status >=400 && status <=599) by app
    | let error_rate = ( ( error / (success + error) ) *100 )
    | sort -error_rate
    ```
    
    | app | success | error | error_rate |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | web | 422,952 | 26,778 | 5.95 |
    | appserver | 364,581 | 21,366 | 5.54 |
    
    To calculate the error rate by region:
    
    ```
    status=*
    | parse "\\w+-$region$" from serverHost
    | group success = count(status >= 200 && status <=299), error = count(status >=400 && status <=599) by region
    | let error_rate = ( ( error / (success + error) ) *100 )
    | sort -error_rate
    ```
    
    | region | success | error | error_rate |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | 2 | 93,730 | 4,268 | 4.36 |
    | 1 | 33,712 | 1,491 | 4.24 |
    | 3 | 59,272 | 2,551 | 4.13 |
- PowerQuery lookup command
    
    You can use the `lookup` to specify columns from a lookup table, and then join them to your query on keys, to update columns in tables in your data lake from a data table configuration file, and also match subnets using Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) from a data table configuration file.
    
    In a `lookup` command you can also specify SentinelOne specific operators in your search query based on the syntax you want to match on in your query.
    
    **Topics**
    
    - [Using the `lookup` command](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006607#UUID-8c3ed5f4-838d-1150-f14a-b7c1b95d731f_N1739499044835)
    - [Supported operators in lookup queries](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006607#UUID-8c3ed5f4-838d-1150-f14a-b7c1b95d731f_N1739499827574)
    - [Supported wildcards in data tables](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006607#UUID-8c3ed5f4-838d-1150-f14a-b7c1b95d731f_N1739499222318)
    - [Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) subnet matching](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006607#UUID-8c3ed5f4-838d-1150-f14a-b7c1b95d731f_N1739499805621)
    
    ## `lookup` syntax
    
    The following code example is shows the general syntax used with the `lookup` command.
    
    ```
    | lookup column, field=column2, "field 3"=column3, ... from tableName by keyColumn, keyColumn2=expression,  ...
    | dataset 'config://path/to/file'
    ```
    
    When creating a `lookup` request the structure is as follows.
    
    - `lookup` gets columns from a lookup table, and joins them to your query on keys.
    - `from` sets the lookup `tableName`.
    - `by` sets the keys to join values on (for example, by [endpoint.name](http://endpoint.name/)=[endpoint.name](http://endpoint.name/)).
    
    Examples that use the `lookup` command.
    
    ```
    | lookup osVersion from machineinfo byendpoint.name
    | lookup osVersion from machineinfo byendpoint.name=endpoint.name
    | lookup osVersion from machineinfo byendpoint.name,os.name
    | dataset 'config://datatables/machineinfo'
    ```
    
    `lookup` only joins the **first** row that satisfies the `by` clause. If there is no match, values are `null`. Matches on `null` are valid: if the expression evaluates to `null`, lookup joins the first row with a matching `null` value.
    
    You can also use the `dataset` command to import a lookup table for use in PowerQueries. The command requires a full, explicit path to the lookup file, with the syntax `'config://full/path/to/file'`.
    
    Select the user menu > **Config Files** to create or edit a JSON or CSV lookup table, at `/datatables/tableName`. For example, consider a table `/datatables/machineinfo` or `/datatables/machineinfo.csv`. This table stores information about the endpoints agents are installed on. The table must be 400 KB or less.
    
    **JSON Format**
    
    ```
    {
        columnNames: ["id", "endpoint.name", "os.name", "osVersion", "region"],
        rows: [
        [111, "Agent-eorct", "Windows 10 Pro", "22H2", "US"],
        [222, "Agent-orbnw", "Windows 10 Pro", "20H2", "US"],
        [333, "Agent-vjfwc", "Windows 10 Pro", "22H2", "US"],
        [444, "Agent-ylauk", "Windows 10 Pro", "22H2", "US"],
        [555, "Agent-pmkbv", "Windows 11", "22H2", "EU"],
        [666, "Agent-swuty", "Windows 11", "21H2", "EU"],
        ]
    }
    ```
    
    Each row must have the same number of entries as `columnNames`. Values in a row can be null, boolean, numbers, or strings.
    
    **CSV Format**
    
    ```
    "id", "endpoint.name", "os.name", "osVersion", "region"
    111,"Agent-eorct","Windows 10 Pro","22H2","US"
    222,"Agent-orbnw","Windows 10 Pro","20H2","US"
    333,"Agent-vjfwc","Windows 10 Pro","22H2","US"
    444,"Agent-ylauk","Windows 10 Pro","22H2","US"
    555,"Agent-pmkbv","Windows 11","22H2","EU"
    666,"Agent-swuty","Windows 11","21H2","EU"
    ```
    
    All entries in a CSV lookup table are strings.
    
    **Example Lookup**
    
    Consider a query to count the number of `indicator.category` events for endpoints with a Windows 10 Pro OS, by [`endpoint.name`](http://endpoint.name/), and `indicator.category`:
    
    ```
    indicator.category=*os.name='Windows 10 Pro'
    | group count=count() byendpoint.name, indicator.category
    ```
    
    | [endpoint.name](http://endpoint.name/) | indicator.category | count |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | Agent-eorct | General | 3 |
    | Agent-obrnw | General | 20 |
    | Agent-vjfwc | General | 3 |
    | Agent-ylauk | General | 3 |
    | Agent-ylauk | InfoStealer | 1 |
    
    The high count for `Agent-orbnw` is an issue. We can lookup the version of the OS in `/datatables/machineinfo` :
    
    ```
    indicator.category=*os.name='Windows 10 Pro'
    | group count=count() byendpoint.name, indicator.category
    | lookup osVersion from machineinfo byendpoint.name
    ```
    
    For a CSV table, `/datatables/machineinfo.csv`:
    
    ```
    indicator.category=*os.name='Windows 10 Pro'
    | group count=count() byendpoint.name, indicator.category
    | lookup osVersion from machineinfo.csv byendpoint.name
    ```
    
    Because the columns to join on have the same name, we only have to set [`endpoint.name`](http://endpoint.name/), instead of [`endpoint.name](http://endpoint.name/)=[endpoint.name](http://endpoint.name/)`. The output table:
    
    | [endpoint.name](http://endpoint.name/) | indicator.category | count | osVersion |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | Agent-eorct | General | 3 | 22H2 |
    | Agent-orbnw | General | 20 | 20H2 |
    | Agent-vjfwc | General | 3 | 22H2 |
    | Agent-ylauk | General | 3 | 22H2 |
    | Agent-ylauk | InfoStealer | 1 | 22H2 |
    
    The older OS version for `Agent-orbnw` may be the problem.
    
    **Example `dataset` Lookup**
    
    Consider a query to calculate the number of events by `indicator.category` for endpoints that have the Windows 10 Pro OS, and an OS version of 20H2. Let's import the `/datatables/machineinfo` table:
    
    ```
    | dataset 'config://datatables/machineinfo'
    ```
    
    | id | [endpoint.name](http://endpoint.name/) | [os.name](http://os.name/) | osVersion | region |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | 111 | Agent-eorct | Windows 10 Pro | 22H2 | US |
    | 222 | Agent-orbnw | Windows 10 Pro | 20H2 | US |
    | 333 | Agent-vjfwc | Windows 10 Pro | 22H2 | US |
    | 444 | Agent-ylauk | Windows 10 Pro | 22H2 | US |
    | 555 | Agent-pmkbv | Windows 11 | 22H2 | EU |
    | 666 | Agent-swuty | Windows 11 | 21H2 | EU |
    
    Next, let's filter the table for the 20H2 OS version:
    
    ```
    | dataset 'config://datatables/machineinfo'
    | filter osVersion='20H2'
    ```
    
    | id | [endpoint.name](http://endpoint.name/) | [os.name](http://os.name/) | osVersion | region |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | 222 | Agent-orbnw | Windows 10 Pro | 20H2 | US |
    
    The `dataset` command lets you use the lookup table in a join to filter data. Whereas the `lookup` command always treats the lookup table as the right table, `dataset` lets you bring the table in from the left, and the join returns all rows from the lookup table. Note that you must set `| columns` to use a lookup table column in the `on` clause of the join:
    
    ```
    | join
    lookup_data = (
      | dataset 'config://datatables/machineinfo'
      | filter osVersion='20H2'
      | columns endpoint, osVersion
    ),
    indicator_data = (
      indicator.category=*os.name='Windows 10 Pro'
      | group count() byendpoint.name, indicator.category
    )
    on endpoint=endpoint.name
    ```
    
    | endpoint | osVersion | indicator.category | count() |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | Agent-orbnw | 20H2 | Evasion | 12 |
    | Agent-orbnw | 20H2 | General | 20 |
    | Agent-orbnw | 20H2 | InfoStealer | 47 |
    | Agent-orbnw | 20H2 | Malware | 3 |
    
    ## Supported operators in `lookup` queries
    
    Data table lookups on resources in SDL are file-based lookups that match field values from your events to field values in a static table represented by your data table. These lookups can output corresponding field values from the table to your events. Data table lookups work best on small sets of data.
    
    The following is the general syntax for a `lookup` query. SentinelOne provides unique operators that enhance syntax matching in your queries.
    
    ```
    | lookup column, field=column2, "field 3"=column3, ... from tableName by keyColumn, keyColumn2=expression, "keyColumn3"=:wildcard expression3, "keyColumn4"=:cidr expression4 ...
    | dataset 'config://path/to/file'
    ```
    
    `operator` refers to one of the support operators in lookups.
    
    **Supported operators in lookup queries**
    
    - `=` — looks for an exact case-sensitive character matches.
    - `=:anycase` — looks for an exact character match but is not case-sensitive.
    - `=: wildcard` — looks for matches based on the wildcard logic specified in the data table.
    - `=: cidr` — matches IP addresses in your data lake to subnets in the data table specified.
    
    **Example `lookup` query using the `=:wildcard` operator**
    
    In this query the **`=:wilcard`** operator is specified. When the search is excuted any supported wildcards found in the specified data table, **`process.csv`** are considered when matching.
    
    ```
    lookupprocess_category=category fromprocesses.csv byfile=:wildcard process
    ```
    
    ## Supported wildcards in data tables
    
    When you upload a new data table it is saved as a **Configuration files** under **Policy & Settings**. To learn more about uploading data tables, see [Defining Parameters Using Data Tables](https://community.sentinelone.com/document/preview/1862401#UUID-23ed8f88-b4d3-33fd-fa28-913ea99f78e0).
    
    Data tables support the following wildcards.
    
    **Supported wildcards in data table configuration files**
    
    - The percent character (`%`), which matches multiple characters in a search query.
    - The underscore character (`_`), which matches a single character.
    
    When using a wildcard consider these best practices.
    
    **Best practices for using wildcards in data table configuration files**
    
    - Use the percent character (`%`) at the end of a term to match multiple characters.
    - Do not use wildcards to match punctuation. Specify the punctuation directly in your search criteria.
    
    When you create a data table for lookups inSDL, follow these best practices.
    
    - One column must contain valid wildcard expressions where `%` matches zero or more characters, and `_` matches exactly one character.
    - Any column can have multiple instances of the same value. For example you have **`____.exe`** in the data table twice, and it maps to two different values like *audit* and *malware*.
    - The column names in your data table don't need to match the column names in SDL.
    - The characters in the file must be plain ASCII text and valid UTF-8 characters. Non-UTF-8 characters are not supported.
    
    **Example CSV data table that includes wildcard elements**
    
    The following example data table shows you how the **`_`** and **`%`** are specified in a data table.
    
    ```
    file, category
    C:\\Documents and Settings\\Default User \\_____.exe, ransomeware
    C:\\System\\%\\spy\\%\\update.exe, spyware
    ```
    
    In this example, the **`_`** wildcard is used to indicate that any 5 character string that proceeds `.exe` would return True, and should be matched to the category ransomware. The **`%`**\\spy\\**`%`** will match match multiple characters from the query. In the example, any file path that contains the `spy` subdirectory would return True.
    
    ## CIDR matching in data tables and `lookup` queries
    
    Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) is a method for allocating IP addresses and IP routing. CIDR is used to create unique identifiers for networks and individual devices, which helps in efficiently managing the allocation of IP addresses.
    
    In the CIDR notation 192.0.2.0/24, the "/24" suffix indicates that the first 24 bits (192.0.2) represent the *network address*, while the remaining 8 bits are used for *host addresses* within that network. This is also known as the prefix length. This allows for a flexible allocation of IP addresses compared to the older classful addressing system.
    
    Matching occurs based on the network address specified in the CIDR notation.
    
    ## Supported network addresses
    
    The lookup command supports IPv4 and IPv6 addresses and subnets that use CIDR notation.
    
    **Required elements in a data table to for CIDR lookups**
    
    - One column must contain the netword address with a forward slash and a number appended to the end. The number denotes the prefix length in bits. For example, if you take the IP address `192.168.1.0/24`, the **`/24`** here indicates that the first 24 bits constitute the network prefix for this address.
    
    When making a `lookup` query use the `=: cidr` operator to indicate that you want to match on the CIDR notation syntax specified in the corresponding data table.
    
    **Example `lookup` query using the `=: cidr` operator**
    
    In this query the **`=: cidr`** is specified. When the search is executed any entries found in the data table **`subnets.csv`** that use CIDR notation will match on the specified network address.
    
    ```
    lookupsubnet_name=name fromsubnet.csv bysubnet=:wildcard ip
    ```
    
- PowerQuery savelookup command
    
    The `savelookup` command saves the PowerQuery result as a lookup table or, more specifically, as a data table in your configuration files. For efficiency, you can use the lookup table—instead of the data lake—in later queries with the `lookup` and `dataset` commands.
    
    ```
    | savelookup '<tableName>'[, 'merge']
    
    ```
    
    - `tableName` sets the name of the lookup table.
        
        By default, the lookup table is saved in JSON format. To instead save the lookup table in CSV format, end the table name with **`.csv`**. Examples:
        
        ```
        | savelookup 'binary_outgoing_publicip'
        | savelookup 'binary_outgoing_publicip.csv'
        ```
        
    - `merge` specifies—when the `tableName` matches an existing lookup table—to merge the new query result with the existing table. Without `merge`, the existing table is overwritten by the new query results.
        
        If the PowerQuery uses a `group` command, the merge is a join of the two tables. If the PowerQuery doesn’t use a `group` command, the merge is a union of the two tables. For more information about joins and unions, see [PowerQueries Join Command](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006609) and [PowerQueries Union Command](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006610).
        
    
    ## Note
    
    - The `savelookup` command is available in the All Data view of Event Search to users with the **SDL Configuration Files - Manage** permission.
    - Each lookup table can have up to 100,000 rows and be up to 1.5 MB, or 390 KB compressed.
    - The `savelookup` command doesn't support arrays in query results. A PowerQuery can create and operate on arrays, but the result can't have arrays.
    
    This example creates a lookup table from a query that counts the number of EventViewerTampering events for each endpoint.
    
    ```
    indicator.name = 'EventViewerTampering'
    | group count=count() by agent.uuid
    | savelookup 'EventViewerTampering events per agent'
    ```
    
    You can use the `dataset` command to load the data from the lookup table into the PowerQuery.
    
    ```
    | dataset 'config://datatables/EventViewerTampering events per agent'
    ```
    
    Or you can open the configuration file. For instructions, see [Configuration Files Overview](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006442).
    
    [](https://community.sentinelone.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka0UW000000LWXx&feoid=00N6900000KUK4a&refid=0EMUW00000H5kq1)
    
    ---
    
    You can rerun the query with a different time range and merge the new query result with the existing lookup table.
    
    ```
    indicator.name = 'EventViewerTampering'
    | group count=count() by agent.uuid
    | savelookup 'EventViewerTampering events per agent', 'merge'
    ```
    
    And you can use other PowerQuery commands to manipulate the data from the lookup table.
    
    ```
    | dataset 'config://datatables/EventViewerTampering events per agent'
    | sort -count
    ```
    
- PowerQuery sort command
    
    The `sort` command orders the output table or records in the query.
    
    ```
    sort expression, expression2, ...
    sort +expression, -expression2, ...
    ```
    
    Examples:
    
    ```
    | sort event.time
    | sort -dst.ip.address
    ```
    
    Examples for Log Analytics:
    
    ```
    | sort -error_rate
    | sort -percent_of_total(requests_real)
    ```
    
    The expression is usually the name of a column to sort on.
    
    If you set many expressions, the sort is on the first, and the others break ties.
    
    `+` sets ascending order, and `-` descending order. The default is ascending.
    
- PowerQuery join command
    
    The `join` command executes two or more queries and merges the results into a single table.
    
    ```
    | [inner, sql inner, left, sql left, outer, sql outer] join [a =] (query), [b =] (query) ... [on x, y, a.z = b.w]
    ```
    
    You must start a join with `| join`. (Without the pipe, we search for the word "join".)
    
    There are different join commands. If not set, the default is `inner`:
    
    - [`inner join`](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006609#UUID-18642d15-0d14-1b92-f08c-7ea44022a8c8_UUID-151b1087-daac-897f-10a8-94e381253a18): The output table has rows from the left table, and the **first** matching row from the right table. If a row in the left table does not match a row in the right, it is removed. A row can match on `null` values.
    - [`sql inner join`](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006609#UUID-18642d15-0d14-1b92-f08c-7ea44022a8c8_UUID-6feb371a-cf93-e362-a0f2-8e23206d4038): The output table has rows from the left table, and **all** matching rows from the right table. If a row in the left table does not match a row in the right, it is removed. A row can match on `null` values.
    - [`left join`](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006609#UUID-18642d15-0d14-1b92-f08c-7ea44022a8c8_UUID-1d389a05-1827-680c-cbc5-9faf31e703d3): The output table has all rows from the left table, and the **first** matching row from the right table. If a row in the left table does not match a row in the right, it is kept, and missing values become `null`. A row can match on `null` values.
    - [`sql left join`](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006609#UUID-18642d15-0d14-1b92-f08c-7ea44022a8c8_UUID-1b4b802a-69a5-5991-0a78-3fd223390bbf): The output table has rows in the left table, and **all** matching rows from the right table. If a row in the left table does not match a row in the right, it is kept, and missing values become `null`. A row can match on `null` values.
    - [`outer join`](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006609#UUID-18642d15-0d14-1b92-f08c-7ea44022a8c8_UUID-8a707926-6874-de2e-7e42-e417c55b1312): The output table has all rows from the left table, and the **first** matching row from the right table. Rows without a match in both tables are kept, and missing values become `null`. A row can match on `null` values.
    - [`sql outer join`](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006609#UUID-18642d15-0d14-1b92-f08c-7ea44022a8c8_UUID-950de0b1-07c0-9745-2b84-d9452ff9bdc0): The output table has **all** rows from the left and right table. Rows without a match in both tables are kept, and missing values become `null`. A row can match on `null` values.
    
    You can set an optional name for each query, for example `a=(query)`. Names must be distinct: they cannot conflict with a field name in a query.
    
    `on` sets the keys to match rows in each query. Each key links column names (usually field names):
    
    - If not set, each row in the first query joins with the first row in the remaining queries.
    - If queries have the same field name, you can join `on fieldName`.
    - If queries have different field names, set `a.x = b.y`. For example, `on queryName1.fieldNameX = queryName2.fieldNameY`.
    - You can use the form `x = y` if the field names are only in one query. For example, `on fieldNameX = fieldNameY`.
    - You cannot link two fields of the same query. For example, `a.x = b.y, b.y = a.z` is not allowed, because `a.x` and `a.z` are linked.
    
    If you nest **join** commands, `join` commands and `union` commands in each query cannot export dotted field names. Rename them with the `columns` command.
    
    The output table from a `join` has the columns of the first query, then the columns of the second query, and so on. Knowing the order is important for the axes in [PowerQuery Graphs](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006614#UUID-3ea313aa-9c2a-e0c4-2a6d-940543359518).
    
    If a field name is in two or more queries, we add the query name. For example, to join a count of events by Storyline™, and a count of indicator events by Storyline™ :
    
    ```
    | join
    events_by_storyline = (src.process.storyline.id=*
    | group count=count() bysrc.process.storyline.id),
    events_by_indicator_category = (indicator.category=*
    | group count=count() bysrc.process.storyline.id)
    onsrc.process.storyline.id
    ```
    
    | [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/) | events_by_storyline.count | events_by_indicator_category.count |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | A153867CED1FF38A | 4,211 | 435 |
    | EBBB787CED1FF38A | 299 | 294 |
    | 07F9687CED1FF38A | 346 | 140 |
    
    This query joins `events_by_storyline` and `events_by_indicator_category` on [`src.process.storyline.id`](http://src.process.storyline.id/). We add the query name to `count` for clarity. We do not add the query name to [`src.process.storyline.id`](http://src.process.storyline.id/) because the field is a key. We also do not add the query name to fields that are only in one query.
    
    `inner join` and `left join` can have a maximum of 10 queries. `sql inner` and `sql left` joins can only have 2 queries. Each query must link to an earlier query by at least one `on` expression.
    
    **Example Queries**
    
    An example join query to attach the command-line to a query for outbound PowerShell communications:
    
    ```
    | join
    (src.process.name matches "powershell" dst.ip.address = *
    | let rfc1918 = not ($dst.ip.address matches "((127\\..*)|(192\\.168\..*)|(10\\..*)|(172\\.1[6-9]\\..*)|(172\\.2[0-9]\\..*)|(172\\.3[0-1]\\..*)).*")
    | filter rfc1918 = true
    | group hits = count(src.process.name), IPs = hacklist(dst.ip.address) byendpoint.name,src.process.name,src.process.storyline.id),
    (src.process.name matches "powershell" src.process.cmdline = *
    | columns src.process.cmdline,src.process.storyline.id)
    onsrc.process.storyline.id
    ```
    
    This join query computes the most executed process for each endpoint, and the count. Note the use of the `max_by` function to calculate the most executed process:
    
    ```
    | join
    most_executed_process_by_endpoint = (event.type = "Process Creation"src.process.name=*
    | group c=count() byendpoint.name,src.process.name
    | group most_executed = max_by(src.process.name, c) byendpoint.name),
    all_procs_by_endpoint = (event.type = "Process Creation"src.process.name=*
    | group cnt=count() byendpoint.name, most_executed=src.process.name)
    onendpoint.name, most_executed
    ```
    
    **Example Query for Log Analytics:**
    
    To calculate disk use by server:
    
    ```
    | join
     (source='tsdb' serverHost=* metric='df.1kblocks.free' mount='/' | group free = average(value) by serverHost),
     (source='tsdb' serverHost=* metric='df.1kblocks.used' mount='/' | group used = average(value) by serverHost)
     on serverHost
     | let percent = (used/(free + used) * 100)
     | columns serverHost, "Disk Use (% of Total)"=percent
    ```
    
    | serverHost | Disk Use (% of Total) |
    | --- | --- |
    | appserver-1 | 42.5 |
    | appserver-2 | 42.5 |
    | appserver-3 | 42.5 |
    | appserver-4 | 42.5 |
    | appserver-5 | 42.5 |
    | appserver-6 | 42.5 |
    | appserver-7 | 42.5 |
    | appserver-8 | 42.5 |
    
    ## Inner Join Examples
    
    Let's create some example data:
    
    Table1:
    
    ```
    | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, b='foo'), // Each "| limit" query finds 1 row of data,
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'), // then overwrites it with "columns".
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')  // "union" them together for a sample table.
    ```
    
    | a | b |
    | --- | --- |
    | 1 | foo |
    | 2 | foo |
    | 2 | bar |
    
    Table2:
    
    ```
    | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    ```
    
    | a | c |
    | --- | --- |
    | 1 | spam |
    | 1 | ham |
    | 2 | eggs |
    | 2 | bacon |
    | 2 | cheese |
    
    An `inner join` adds the **first** matching row from Table2. The word "inner" is optional:
    
    ```
    | join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 1 | foo | spam |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    
    If there is no match, for example `a=3`, then the row is removed:
    
    ```
    | join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=3, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 1 | foo | spam |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    
    Unlike SQL, joins on `null` are valid:
    
    ```
    | join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | - | foo | spam |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    
    ## SQL Inner Join Examples
    
    A `sql inner join` adds **all** matching rows from the right table. The word "inner" is optional:
    
    ```
    | sql join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 1 | foo | spam |
    | 1 | foo | ham |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | foo | bacon |
    | 2 | foo | cheese |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | bacon |
    | 2 | bar | cheese |
    
    If there is no match, for example `a=3`, then the row is removed:
    
    ```
    | sql inner join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=3, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | foo | bacon |
    | 2 | foo | cheese |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | bacon |
    | 2 | bar | cheese |
    
    Unlike SQL, joins on `null` are valid:
    
    ```
    | sql inner join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | - | foo | spam |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | foo | bacon |
    | 2 | foo | cheese |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | bacon |
    | 2 | bar | cheese |
    
    ## Left Join Examples
    
    A `left join` only adds the **first** matching row from the right table:
    
    ```
    | left join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 1 | foo | spam |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    
    Rows without a match are kept, for example `a=3`. Missing values become `null`:
    
    ```
    | left join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=3, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 3 | foo | - |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    
    Unlike SQL, joins on `null` are valid:
    
    ```
    | left join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | - | foo | spam |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    
    ## SQL Left Join Examples
    
    An `sql left join` adds **all** matching rows from the right table:
    
    ```
    | sql left join

    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')

    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ```

    | 2 | foo | cheese |

    ```
    on a
    ```

    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 3 | foo | - |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | foo | bacon |
    | 2 | foo | cheese |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | bacon |
    | 2 | bar | cheese |
    
    Unlike SQL, joins on `null` are valid:
    
    ```
    | sql left join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, c='spam'),

    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```

    | --- | --- | --- |

    ## Outer Join Examples
    
    An `outer join` only adds the first matching row from the right table:
    
    ```
    | outer join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 1 | foo | spam |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    
    Rows without a match in both tables are kept, for example `a=1` and `a=3`. Missing values become `null`:
    
    ```
    | outer join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=3, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 3 | foo | - |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    | 1 | - | ham |
    
    Unlike SQL, joins on `null` are valid:
    
    ```
    | outer join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | - | foo | spam |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    | 1 | - | ham |
    
    ## SQL Outer Join Examples
    
    An `sql outer join` is similar to a SQL full outer join. It adds **all** matching rows from the left and right tables:
    
    ```
    | sql outer join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 1 | foo | spam |
    | 1 | foo | ham |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | foo | bacon |
    | 2 | foo | cheese |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | bacon |
    | 2 | bar | cheese |
    
    Rows without a match in both tables are kept, for example `a=1` and `a=3`. Missing values become `null`:
    
    ```
    | sql outer join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=3, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 3 | foo | - |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | foo | bacon |
    | 2 | foo | cheese |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | bacon |
    | 2 | bar | cheese |
    | 1 | - | ham |
    
    Unlike SQL, joins on `null` are valid:
    
    ```
    | sql outer join
    Table1 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='foo'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, b='bar')
    ),
    Table2 = ( | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=null, c='spam'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=1, c='ham'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='eggs'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='bacon'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns a=2, c='cheese')
    )
    on a
    ```
    
    | a | b | c |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | - | foo | spam |
    | 2 | foo | eggs |
    | 2 | foo | bacon |
    | 2 | foo | cheese |
    | 2 | bar | eggs |
    | 2 | bar | bacon |
    | 2 | bar | cheese |
    | 1 | - | ham |
- PowerQuery union command
    
    The `union` command executes two or more queries, and merges the results into a single table.
    
    ```
    | union (query), (query), ...
    ```
    
    You must start a union with `| union`. (Without the pipe, we search for the word "union".)
    
    Unlike an SQL union, the queries can output a different number of columns and different data types. The output table has all rows and all columns from each query, in the order set in the command. If a column is present in one query but not another, the values are `null` in the output table.
    
    The output does not have a sort sequence, even if each query is sorted. Use the `sort` command after a union to order the data.
    
    A union can have at most 10 queries.
    
    **Example Queries**
    
    A simple query to find events where the `tgt.file.path` contains 'temp", and merge them with events where the `tgt.file.oldPath` contains 'temp':
    
    ```
    | union
    (tgt.file.path contains 'temp'
    | columns event.time , event.type,event.id, tgt.file.path),
    (tgt.file.oldPath contains 'temp'
    | columns event.time , event.type,event.id, tgt.file.path)
    ```
    
    | Event Time | Event type | Event ID | Target File Path |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | Jun 5 · 11:30:03.304 am | File Deletion | 01H269RBR8X4FATE7QKAABQVKP_106 | C://TEMP |
    | Jun 5 · 11:30:02.949 am | File Rename | 01H269RBR8X4FATE7QKAABQVKP_87 | C://TEMP//NzrPvQVSDe//UFzVwPwwNN.BhCzwEmvOz |
    | Jun 5 · 11:30:02.949 am | File Rename | 01H269RBR8X4FATE7QKAABQVKP_87 | C://TEMP//NzrPvQVSDe//UFzVwPwwNN.BhCzwEmvOz |
    
    The output has two rows for the same event , with Event ID `01H269RBR8X4FATE7QKAABQVKP_87`. This event has a `tgt.file.path`, and a `tgt.file.oldPath` with 'temp' in the path. Both queries in the `union` retrieved this event.
    
    You can write the query without `union` to prevent duplicate events :
    
    ```
    (tgt.file.path contains 'temp') or (tgt.file.oldPath contains 'temp')
    | columns event.time , event.type,event.id, tgt.file.path)
    ```
    
    | Event Time | Event type | Event ID | Target File Path |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | Jun 5 · 11:30:03.304 am | File Deletion | 01H269RBR8X4FATE7QKAABQVKP_106 | C://TEMP |
    | Jun 5 · 11:30:02.949 am | File Rename | 01H269RBR8X4FATE7QKAABQVKP_87 | C://TEMP//NzrPvQVSDe//UFzVwPwwNN.BhCzwE |
    
    Because EDR and XDR data has a well-defined schema, most Process State Queries do not require `union`, and can be rewritten as a `filter` command, with operators such as `or`.
    
    For other data sources, for example logs ingested with the SentinelOne Collector, `union` can be very useful. Suppose you import application logs. The API server has these events:
    
    ```
    operation=getTopItems elapsed_time=372 status_code=200
    operation=getTopItems elapsed_time=409 status_code=200
    operation=getTopItems elapsed_time=5999 status_code=502
    ```
    
    | operation | elapsed_time | status_code |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | getTopItems | 372 | 200 |
    | getTopItems | 409 | 200 |
    | getTopItems | 5,999 | 502 |
    
    The "frontend server" has these events. Without a well-defined schema, the HTTP status code has a different field name:
    
    ```
    url=/home http_status=200
    url=/home http_status=200
    url=/info http_status=404
    ```
    
    | url | http_status |
    | --- | --- |
    | /home | 200 |
    | /home | 200 |
    | /info | 404 |
    
    The output of a `union` has all unique columns in all queries. Missing values become `null`:
    
    ```
    | union
      (logfile='api_server' | columns operation, elapsed_time, status_code),
      (logfile='frontend'   | columns url, http_status)
    ```
    
    | operation | elapsed_time | status_code | url | http_status |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | getTopItems | 372 | 200 | - | - |
    | getTopItems | 409 | 200 | - | - |
    | getTopItems | 5,999 | 502 | - | - |
    | - | - | - | /home | 200 |
    | - | - | - | /home | 200 |
    | - | - | - | /info | 404 |
    
    To merge `status_code` and `http_status`, assign the same name:
    
    ```
    | union
      (logfile='api_server' | columns operation, elapsed_time, status = status_code),
      (logfile='frontend'   | columns url, status = http_status)
    ```
    
    | operation | elapsed_time | status_code | url |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | getTopItems | 372 | 200 |  |
    | getTopItems | 409 | 200 |  |
    | getTopItems | 5,999 | 502 |  |
    |  |  | 200 | /home |
    |  |  | 200 | /home |
    |  |  | 404 | /info |
    
    You can then use `group` to count each status code. A `join` cannot do this:
    
    ```
    | union
      (logfile='api_server' | columns operation, elapsed_time, status = status_code),
      (logfile='frontend'   | columns url, status = http_status)
    | group count() by status
    ```
    
    | status | count() |
    | --- | --- |
    | 200 | 4 |
    | 404 | 1 |
    | 502 | 1 |
- PowerQuery transpose command
    
    The `transpose` removes a column from the table and transposes it.
    
    ```
    | transpose column
    | transpose column on column1, column2, ...
    | transpose column on column1, column2, ... with_totals
    | transpose column on column1, column2, ... limit NNN
    | transpose column on column1, column2, ... limit NNN with_totals
    
    ```
    
    Examples:
    
    ```
    | transpose indicator.category
    | transpose indicator.category on timestamp
    
    ```
    
    Examples for Log Analytics:
    
    ```
    | transpose serverHost
    | transpose serverHost on timestamp
    | transpose serverHost on year, month, day
    ```
    
    Each unique value in the column is used to create new columns. Columns after "on" are row keys: their values are not transposed. The command must be the last in the query, and cannot be in a subquery.
    
    Consider a query to calculate the most prevalent values of `indicator.category` for each Storyline™ :
    
    ```
    indicator.category=*src.process.storyline.id=*
    | group count=count() by indicator.category,src.process.storyline.id
    | sort -count
    
    ```
    
    | [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/) | indicator.category | count |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | EBBB787CED1FF38A | General | 16 |
    | EBBB787CED1FF38A | InfoStealer | 2 |
    | C7E5867CED1FF38A | General | 2 |
    | 44BF787CED1FF38A | InfoStealer | 2 |
    | 44BF787CED1FF38A | Evasion | 2 |
    
    If we add `| transpose indicator.category on [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/)`:
    
    | [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/) | Evasion | General | InfoStealer |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | EBBB787CED1FF38A | - | 16 | 2 |
    | C7E5867CED1FF38A | - | 2 | - |
    | 44BF787CED1FF38A | 2 | - | 2 |
    
    `indicator.category` is the transpose column. Its values are transposed, and used to create the columns `Evasion`, `General`, and `InfoStealer`. [`src.process.storyline.id`](http://src.process.storyline.id/),  is the key column, and its values are not transposed. You can now view counts for each Storyline™ on one row.
    
    `transpose` changes the table orientation, usually for presentations, or to format time series data for PowerQueryP Graphs. Multiple key columns are supported. For example, we can add the `timebucket()` function to the above query to calculate counts for each hour:
    
    ```
    indicator.category=*src.process.storyline.id=*
    | group count=count() by timestamp=timebucket("1h"), indicator.category,src.process.storyline.id
    ```
    
    | timestamp | indicator.category | [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/) | count |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | May 31 · 4:00:00.000 pm | General | EBBB787CED1FF38A | 6 |
    | May 31 · 4:00:00.000 pm | InfoStealer | EBBB787CED1FF38A | 1 |
    | May 31 · 5:00:00.000 pm | General | EBBB787CED1FF38A | 5 |
    | May 31 · 5:00:00.000 pm | InfoStealer | EBBB787CED1FF38A | 1 |
    | May 31 · 5:00:00.000 pm | General | C7E5867CED1FF38A | 1 |
    | May 31 · 6:00:00.000 pm | General | EBBB787CED1FF38A | 5 |
    | May 31 · 6:00:00.000 pm | Evasion | 44BF787CED1FF38A | 2 |
    | May 31 · 6:00:00.000 pm | InfoStealer | 44BF787CED1FF38A | 2 |
    
    If we add `| transpose indicator.category on timestamp, [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/)`:
    
    | timestamp | [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/) | Evasion | General | InfoStealer |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | May 31 · 4:00:00.000 pm | EBBB787CED1FF38A | - | 6 | 1 |
    | May 31 · 5:00:00.000 pm | EBBB787CED1FF38A | - | 5 | 1 |
    | May 31 · 5:00:00.000 pm | C7E5867CED1FF38A | - | 2 | - |
    | May 31 · 6:00:00.000 pm | EBBB787CED1FF38A | - | 5 | - |
    | May 31 · 6:00:00.000 pm | 44BF787CED1FF38A | 2 | - | 2 |
    
    Set `limit NNN` and `limit -NNN` to only transpose the NNN column values with the highest or lowest values in the output table:
    
    ```
    indicator.category=*src.process.storyline.id=*
    | group count=count() by timestamp=timebucket("1h"), indicator.category,src.process.storyline.id
    | transpose indicator.category on timestamp,src.process.storyline.id limit 1
    ```
    
    | timestamp | [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/) | General |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | May 31 · 4:00:00.000 pm | EBBB787CED1FF38A | 6 |
    | May 31 · 5:00:00.000 pm | EBBB787CED1FF38A | 5 |
    | May 31 · 5:00:00.000 pm | C7E5867CED1FF38A | 2 |
    | May 31 · 6:00:00.000 pm | EBBB787CED1FF38A | 5 |
    | May 31 · 6:00:00.000 pm | 44BF787CED1FF38A | - |
    
    Set `with_totals` to add a `total` column to the transposed table, and sum across columns. This is useful for reports, where table totals are often presented. The column name cannot be changed. For example:
    
    ```
    indicator.category=*src.process.storyline.id=*
    | group totals=count() by indicator.category,src.process.storyline.id
    | transpose indicator.category onsrc.process.storyline.id with_totals
    ```
    
    | [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/) | Evasion | General | InfoStealer | total |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | EBBB787CED1FF38A | - | 16 | 2 | 18 |
    | C7E5867CED1FF38A | - | 2 | - | 2 |
    | 44BF787CED1FF38A | 2 | - | 2 | 4 |
    | 29E6867CED1FF38A | - | 1 | - | 1 |
    | 0FE6867CED1FF38A | - | 1 | - | 1 |
    
    `transpose` creates a maximum of 100 new columns from the transpose column. If there are more unique values, the 100 most frequent are used.
    
    If `on` is not set, we infer the key columns. We recommend you set `on` for clarity.
    
    If rows have the same values for the transpose column and the key columns, the value from the last row "wins". An example that uses the `union` command with `limit 1` and `columns` to create test data:
    
    ```
    | union
    ( | limit 1 | columns time=1, 'indicator.category'='Evasion',     'src.process.storyline.id'='EBBB787CED1FF38A'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns time=1, 'indicator.category'='General',     'src.process.storyline.id'='EBBB787CED1FF38A'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns time=1, 'indicator.category'='InfoStealer', 'src.process.storyline.id'='EBBB787CED1FF38A'),
    ( | limit 1 | columns time=1, 'indicator.category'='General',     'src.process.storyline.id'='C7E5867CED1FF38A')
    | transpose time onsrc.process.storyline.id
    ```
    
    | [src.process.storyline.id](http://src.process.storyline.id/) | indicator.category |
    | --- | --- |
    | EBBB787CED1FF38A | InfoStealer |
    | C7E5867CED1FF38A | General |
    
    **Example Queries**
    
    A query to calculate the number of endpoint agents that were online and active each hour:
    
    ```
    agent.uuid=*
    | group agents=estimate_distinct(agent.uuid) bysite.name, timestamp = timebucket(timestamp, "1h")
    | columns timestamp,site.name, agents
    ```
    
    The output table:
    
    | [site.name](http://site.name/) | [site.name](http://site.name/) | agents |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | May 24 · 7:00:00.000 pm | Site A | 1 |
    | May 24 · 7:00:00.000 pm | Site B | 3 |
    | May 24 · 8:00:00.000 pm | Site A | 2 |
    | May 24 · 8:00:00.000 pm | Site B | 3 |
    | May 24 · 9:00:00.000 pm | Site A | 1 |
    | May 24 · 9:00:00.000 pm | Site B | 3 |
    
    To plot the number of `agents` for each [`site.name`](http://site.name/) over time, you must transpose the table:
    
    ```
    agent.uuid=*
    | group agents=estimate_distinct(agent.uuid) bysite.name, timestamp = timebucket(timestamp, "1h")
    | columns timestamp,site.name, agents
    | transposesite.name on timestamp
    ```
    
    | timestamp | Site A | Site B |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | May 24 · 7:00:00.000 pm | 1 | 3 |
    | May 24 · 8:00:00.000 pm | 2 | 3 |
    | May 24 · 9:00:00.000 pm | 1 | 3 |
    
    When you switch this table to Line Graph, the number of agents for each [`site.name`](http://site.name/) are graphed as a time series.
    
    **Example Queries for Log Analytics:**
    
    A query to calculate HTTP errors and latency per server. We group by `serverHost` and `timebucket()` to create a time series:
    
    ```
    status >= 400 status <= 599
    | group errorCount=count(), latency=sum(time) by serverHost, timestamp=timebucket('1h')
    | columns timestamp, serverHost, latency, errorCount
    ```
    
    The output table:
    
    | timestamp | serverHost | latency | errorCount |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | Feb 14 · 9:00:00.000 pm | A | 501 | 11 |
    | Feb 14 · 10:00:00.000 pm | A | 601 | 21 |
    | Feb 14 · 11:00:00.000 pm | A | 701 | 31 |
    | Feb 14 · 9:00:00.000 pm | B | 502 | 12 |
    | Feb 14 · 10:00:00.000 pm | B | 602 | 22 |
    | Feb 14 · 11:00:00.000 pm | B | 702 | 32 |
    | Feb 14 · 9:00:00.000 pm | C | 503 | 13 |
    | Feb 14 · 10:00:00.000 pm | C | 603 | 23 |
    | Feb 14 · 11:00:00.000 pm | C | 703 | 33 |
    
    To plot a time series of `latency` and `errorCount` for each `serverHost`, you must transpose the table. As is, if you switch from **Table** to **Line Graph**, the graph only has a plot of latency over time for serverHost C. To transpose:
    
    ```
    status >= 400 status <= 599
    | group errorCount=count(), latency=sum(time) by serverHost, timestamp=timebucket('1h')
    | columns timestamp, serverHost, latency, errorCount
    | transpose serverHost on timestamp
    ```
    
    | timestamp | latency(serverHost A) | latency(serverHost B) | latency(serverHost C) | errorCount(serverHost A) | errorCount(serverHost B) | errorCount(serverHost C) |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | Feb 14 · 9:00:00.000 pm | 501 | 502 | 503 | 11 | 12 | 13 |
    | Feb 14 · 10:00:00.000 pm | 601 | 602 | 603 | 21 | 22 | 23 |
    | Feb 14 · 11:00:00.000 pm | 701 | 702 | 703 | 31 | 32 | 33 |
    
    Each unique value in the transpose column (`serverHost`) is used to create new columns. `on` sets `timestamp` as a key column, which is not transposed. The remaining columns in the table, `latency` and `errorCount`, combine with the transpose column, into `latency(serverHost A)`, `latency(serverHost B)`, and so on.
    
    When you switch this table to **Line Graph**, there are separate time series plots for `latency` and `errorCount`, for each `serverHost`. `timestamp` is the X-axis, and the other columns are separate Y-axis plots.
    
- PowerQuery compare command
    
    The compare command is used to query across time to identify patterns, trends, and anomalies. The command issues the same query, shifted backwards or forwards in time, and puts the results in separate columns.
    
    ```
    | compare [name = ] timeshift('[+,-]<timespan>')
    | compare [name = ] timeshift([+,-]queryspan())
    ```
    
    - A `name` for the compare column or columns is optional.
    - `+` or  shifts the query forwards or backwards in time, and defaults to  when not set.
    - `timespan` sets the amount of time to shift the query. Shortcuts such as `5w`, `5d`, `5h`, `5m`, and `5s` identify five weeks, days, hours, minutes, and seconds.
    - `queryspan()` matches the length of the query time range so that the shifted query is over the immediately preceding (or immediately subsequent) time range of the same length. For example, If the query window is 1 day, then the shifted query is for the previous day (or the next day).
    
    Examples:
    
    ```
    | compare last_week=timeshift('1week')
    | compare next_hour=timeshift('+1h')
    | compare previous_period=timeshift(queryspan())
    | compare next_period=timeshift(+queryspan())
    | compare timeshift('-1d')
    ```
    
    The command must be the last in a query. Only one timeshift is currently supported.
    
    The time range of the shifted query stays the same. For example, if the original query is over the past four hours, and `| compare timeshift('-1d')` is added to shift the query backwards one day, then the shifted query is over the past four hours from one day ago (the past 28 to 24 hours).
    
    ## Example Queries
    
    Consider a query to count the number of `EventViewerTampering` events for each endpoint in the past four hours:
    
    ```
    indicator.name = "EventViewerTampering"
    | group count=count() by agent.uuid
    | sort -count
    ```
    
    The result:
    
    **Count of EventViewerTampering for each Endpoint**
    
    | Agent UUID | Count |
    | --- | --- |
    | 7a981b67fdd04c97a015e8a974d7dbad | 401 |
    | 69fad8cfe158432782ff7918c2019a5a | 31 |
    | f0ae6e7d8235428286e7d8ee48025654 | 23 |
    
    Agent `7a981b67fdd04c97a015e8a974d7dbad` has significantly more `EventViewerTampering` events than other endpoints.
    
    To compare the results against the same query from one week ago:
    
    ```
    indicator.name = "EventViewerTampering"
    | group Count=count() by agent.uuid
    | sort -Count
    | compare last_week=timeshift('1w')
    ```
    
    The result:
    
    **Count of EventViewerTampering for each Endpoint, Compared to the Past Week**
    
    | Agent UUID | Count | Count (last_week) |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | 7a981b67fdd04c97a015e8a974d7dbad | 401 | 30 |
    | 69fad8cfe158432782ff7918c2019a5a | 31 | null |
    | f0ae6e7d8235428286e7d8ee48025654 | 23 | 20 |
    
    Agent `7a981b67fdd04c97a015e8a974d7dbad` had a significant increase in `EventViewerTampering` compared to the past week.
    
    Note the `null` for Agent `69fad8cfe158432782ff7918c2019a5a`, which occurs when there is no data from the query. This Agent was offline last week. Also note also the use of `sort` to sequence the table before `compare`, because `compare` must be the last command in the query.
    
    When used with the `timebucket()` function, `compare` easily creates time series data for graphing. For example, let's count the total number of behavioral indicator events and estimate the distinct number of events for Agent `7a981b67fdd04c97a015e8a974d7dbad`, for each day in the past week. Let's also compare the data to the week before:
    
    ```
    indicator.name=* agent.uuid='3a8e6905725e4f19928be1dffdc4e31d'
    | group Count=count(), Distinct=estimate_distinct(indicator.name) by timestamp=timebucket('1d')
    | compare last_week=timeshift('1w')
    ```
    
    The result:
    
    **Indicator Events and Events by Indicator Name for Agent 7a981b67fdd04c97a015e8a974d7dbad, Compared to the Week Before**
    
    | timestamp | Count | Distinct | Count (last_week) | Distinct (last_week) |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | March 26 6:00 PM | 90 | 37 | 105 | 30 |
    | March 27 6:00 PM | 110 | 20 | 100 | 26 |
    | March 28 6:00 PM | 101 | 24 | 89 | 24 |
    | March 29 6:00 PM | 500 | 17 | 121 | 90 |
    | March 30 6:00 PM | 899 | 19 | 115 | 105 |
    | March 31 6:00 PM | 907 | 15 | 100 | 103 |
    | April 1 6:00 PM | 1215 | 24 | 90 | 110 |
    
    The spike in events on March 29 suggests an attack. To graph plots of the data, click **Table**, then click **Line** or **Bar/Column**. See [PowerQueries Graphs](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006614#UUID-3ea313aa-9c2a-e0c4-2a6d-940543359518) for more.
    
    ## Example Queries for Log Analytics
    
    Consider a query to count the number of server error events for each host in the past four hours:
    
    ```
    status >= 500 && status <= 599
    | group Count=count() by serverHost
    | sort -Count
    ```
    
    The result:
    
    **Count of Server Error Events for each Host**
    
    | serverHost | Count |
    | --- | --- |
    | app2 | 300 |
    | app3 | 23 |
    | app1 | 21 |
    
    To compare the results against the same query from one week ago:
    
    ```
    status >= 500 && status <= 599
    | group Count=count() by serverHost
    | sort -Count
    | compare last_week=timeshift('1w')
    ```
    
    The result:
    
    **Count of Server Error Events for each Host, Compared to Last Week**
    
    | serverHost | Count | Count (last_week) |
    | --- | --- | --- |
    | app2 | 300 | 23 |
    | app3 | 23 | 20 |
    | app1 | 21 | null |
    
    Note the `null` for `app1`, which occurs when there is no data from the query. This host was offline last week. Also note the use of `sort` to sequence the table before `compare`, because `compare` must be the last command in the query.
    
    When used with the `timebucket()` function, `compare` easily creates time series data for graphs. For example, consider a query to calculate the average and 95th percentile of latency for each hour for the past six hours, then compare the results to the week before:
    
    ```
    latency=*
    | group Average=average(latency), 95th=p95(latency) by timestamp=timebucket('1h')
    | compare last_week=timeshift('1w')
    ```
    
    The result:
    
    **Average and 95th Percentile of Latency for each Host, and Compared to Last Week**
    
    | timestamp | Average | 95th | Average (last_week) | 95th (last_week) |
    | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
    | April 1 10:00 AM | 257 | 1,332 | 230 | 1,392 |
    | April 1 11:00 AM | 251 | 1,367 | 250 | 1,389 |
    | April 1 12:00 PM | 261 | 1,361 | 242 | 1,377 |
    | April 1 1:00 PM | 268 | 1,364 | 248 | 1,365 |
    | April 1 2:00 PM | 274 | 1,388 | 252 | 1,383 |
- PowerQuery function reference
    
    PowerQueries support these functions in expressions:
    
    - [Numeric](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006612#UUID-5861e993-6612-bf3c-1a2e-0ca933369d08_id_numericfunctions)
    - [JSON](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006612#UUID-5861e993-6612-bf3c-1a2e-0ca933369d08_sidebar-idm4561253204958434184798393296)
    - [String](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006612#UUID-5861e993-6612-bf3c-1a2e-0ca933369d08_id_stringfunctions)
    - [Network](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006612#UUID-5861e993-6612-bf3c-1a2e-0ca933369d08_id_networkfunctions)
    - [Functions to Aggregate Data Across Rows](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006612#UUID-5861e993-6612-bf3c-1a2e-0ca933369d08_id_functionstoaggregatedataacrossrows)
    - [Array](https://community.sentinelone.com/s/article/000006612#UUID-5861e993-6612-bf3c-1a2e-0ca933369d08_sidebar-idm454993527422563382328090169)
